Early Access Review
								I generally don't write negative reviews unless something is truly amiss.  DISCLAIMER: THIS IS MORE OF A CONSUMER WARNING THAN A REVIEW. One view of the forums or the recent reviews will tell you everything you need to know.  Vertigo Games has been abusing the Early Access Program to build a game on the backs of duped early adopters. What they promised years ago was to deliver a randomly generated, open world diving simulator with unparalleled realism, graphics, and gameplay.  What they have delivered over the past couple of years is a completely unstable, unplayable fantasy game with built-in monetization and in-game purchases, with small and broken maps.  Their screenshots DO NOT match the actual gameplay.  When the game used to work, it was a multiplayer gameplay clone of Depth Hunter 2: Deep Drive, a decent if barren clone.  Starting in November 2014, World of Diving has become the culmination of false promises of progress, game-breaking bugs, eye-splitting visual glitches, dysfunctional online servers (used for authentication and multiplayer), a failed and forced migration to Unity 5, and a game with a backward-moving progress bar...all which make for a very angry user community.  But alas, you can help!  They request additional cash donations on their website in return for future updates.  To add insult to injury, updates are so broken, you are sometimes forced to redownload the previous (and still broken) version.  Each update is roughly 2GB in size.  Each is released with "new features" that no one asked for or wanted, and introduces new glitches while none of the on-going game-breaking bugs seem to get fixed.  There is something called Quality Assurance and Testing, which shouldn't be confused with a Beta Community. It's all very frustrating.  So this kind of business practice doesn't work for very long, and word has gotten out.  Now, this multiplayer game has literally nigh zero players, new or old ( http://steamcharts.com/app/251890#All ), the money stream has run dry, and Vertigo Games has already repurposed many of their developers to work on other projects.  In the summer of 2015, after years of retail availability as a playable and ever-improving Beta, Vertigo Games demoted World of Diving from Beta to Alpha on the Official World of Diving Website (with no communication about that on Steam).  It has become that broken now.After over a year on Steam, in an endless spiral of worse update after worse update, it's amazing that this kind of baitware can still be sold to new, unsuspecting consumers. How Vertigo Games goes about their business is atrocious and offencive, and they should all be very ashamed of taking advantage of their early adopters and taking thousands of dollars in "donations" for false deliverables, and finally, for providing such a HORRIBLE Early Access experience.STAY AWAY FROM THIS GAME/DEVELOPER AND WARN YOUR FRIENDS.  I ask that you please rate this up.

That being said I would like to offer a word of caution only so that people know that they're buying into now and don't potentially complain in the reviews.In it's current state there isn't much to do beyond dive in the available areas and simply explore.   Introduction            	World of Diving is an amazingly beautiful and relaxing diving simulator. I found myself just wandering/swimming around the different levels just looking at the beautiful ocean life and ship wreaks. World of Diving is a great break from the usual fast-paced shooters, but it is not without faults. The in game “dive shop”, where you buy customizations, is filled with micro-transactions. World of Diving also supports VR and player created content. (I’m waiting for steam workshop to be implemented) Even with the faults of this game, the multiplayer is a huge reason to buy this. It is tons of fun exploring the ocean with a few other friends.  Pros                Beautiful graphics Several varied maps/locations Easy and fun multiplayer Tons of customizations  Beautiful and interactive ocean life Plenty to do Very relaxing VR support    Cons               Requires secondary sign-in Micro-transactions  Very slow movement Slow updates Repetitive “objectives”     Conclusion                 	World of Diving is a beautiful and relaxing diving simulator, but it is not without faults. There is a few issues with buying customizations and as well as the fact of the updates are taking forever to come out. Even with the few issues (will most likely be fixed before release) the multiplayer is a huge asset for World of Diving. If you are looking for a relaxing game to play by yourself or with friends this is for you. Don’t expect anything fast paced and exciting.  Video Review

Early Access Review
TL;DR: (On top because of convinience)Do i recommend this? Really hard to say as this title is so very different. If you want some underwater action or competition or a challenge then this is as wrong as a game could be.If you like a total relaxing chill from time to time without the slightest pressure at all, or simply like diving (although this is by no means a diving-simulator!), this one could be of your taste.Can you even call "World of Diving" a "game"? There is no real goal, no enemies, no story, no threat, not even the fear of running out of oxygen and no deeper meaning at all. You just go, well, diving and do, well, diver-stuff. For that you have some tools at your disposal like the Metal-Detector (for finding gold), the camera for taking photos (you don't say!), the diver propulsion vehicle (DPV) for getting around faster.On each map (there are around 9 at the time of writing) you can do some missions or even "challenges" (some with, some without a timelimit) for which you'll get some gold. These missions consist of stuff like "photograph these 3 fishes" and the likes.Also there is a mission-editor which lets you create your own stuff, and on each map you could do missions others have created.What is the purpose of all this you may ask? Consider this game a total relaxing chilling "game". You don't have to race time, there is nothing to win, you can't even fight anything and nothing will hurt you either.And you can even do this online with others (there is no chat, you'll have to communicate with handsigns. Nice idea). But to keep you mildly motivated to relax even more, there is a progression. You will get XP for missionswhich will "level" your character. The higher you'll get, the more stuff to equip your character will be unlocked. Among those are e.g. cute companions like a clownfish or even a shark.But there is a dark side too. An itemshop. Yes. An itemshop for a totally non-competitive game :-)Right now these items are all of cosmetic nature and you could get the bought items by collecting too (which of course will take much more time). Still it leaves a bitter taste for the critical customer.One thing to really judge in this title are the graphics: Really fitting, nothing next-gen but still beautiful. Yet quite demanding. With my rig (see profile) i won't get higher than 30-60fps on Ultra with FullHD.But OK, it's early access, and if you're fine with lower fps that is totally acceptable for a title like this.BTW it supports Occulus Rift, but no 3D-Vision yet (DarkStarSword, the holy knight of 3D-Vision-fixing is working on a fix though).

Early Access Review
								World of Diving feels like something I *want* to like, but it's too inconsistent at this stage.  Graphically, it's quite beautiful.  The undersea world is rendered with appropriate murkiness; fish and dolphins flit about, sharks glide menacingly overhead, and shipwrecks look suitably weathered.But that's about where it ends for me.  As nice as it looks, the ocean in World of Diving seems too static and artificial.  The fauna just swim about without much regard for the player.  The undersea wrecks are impressive, but non-interactive.  It looks real, but it doesn't feel real.In fact, the only undersea interactivity is in the form of contrived "challenges" or hunting for coins or pearls.  Those elements don't really fit with the more realistic presentation.  It's like the developers are attempting to shoehorn a game into a simulation.  The result ends up jarring; I was simultaneously immersed in a wondrous environment and yet constantly reminded that I am playing a video game.My recommendation would be to allow an option to ditch the more obvious "game" like elements in favor of a more immersive experience with better interaction with the undersea world.Updated August 15/2015: Since my original review, I've been following the game's development hoping it would get better with time.  Unfortunately, it hasn't.A few months back the developers migrated from Unity 4 to Unity 5.  The upgrade took several months and introduced a host of bugs and graphical issues with it.  Despite the engine upgrade, the game feels like it's taken a step back particularly with the water graphics.The game's popularity has also dwindled, with typically no more than a couple people playing at any given time.  For a game that boasts multiplayer, not having any players renders that feature moot.  Add on periodic server connection issues and you have a situation that doesn't seem too optimistic.The developers also revealed a roadmap of future game features, but other than improved fish AI, there isn't much to get excited about on that list.  Anyone looking for a more hardcore diving simulator is going to walk away disappointed.This game is simply not worth the money and the way it is being developed, probably won't ever be.  Pick up Subnautica instead.  It's a much better underwater game.

								Update 13.10.2016A year has passed and it's time to see whats new. This time i can say that there have been some changes! A mission structure has been added. No longer can you start new levels from the menu before enough tasks has been completed in the previous. It took about an hour to complete the tasks in tutorial level, before another map opened. These tasks are the worst kind of fetch quests that make you go from A to B and back to A so much, that i wrote my notes while playing with the other hand. This also speaks about how much input the swimming requires. I had to force myself to complete it. There are still "Coming soon" notes around but not as much. Maybe it's because most of the content is no longer available from the start and i'll never waste the time required to open the later levels. A load of collectables have been added to the levels. In the tutorial alone, there are 118 pieces of treasures, 8 pearls and 271 pieces of trash. I collected a total of about 90 while playing and was rewarded with nothing. The collectables make no sense anyway, since they are mostly the same and placed seemingly at random.Camera has been changed from DSLR type to a tablet style device. This brings needless issues with the UI since the device also acts as main menu, mission list etc and it's hard to land on the thing you want. You can no longer leave the camera floating and take selfies with it, which was one of my favourite things a year ago. I cant remember if zooming and other things were in the game a year ago, but they are no longer. The camera in it's current state is really limited.The game runs fine now even at highest settings but the terrain twists and bends as the player gets closer and more detail is added. This seems really odd since the draw distance is really low underwater anyway and even at it's best World of Diving looks dated. Currently the game has no shadows anywhere. Not just real time shadows, even the pre-calculated shadows of stationary objects are missing. This makes the game look really flat and dull.Fishes react to the player but not as creatures with AI. Instead a magical force pushes them away from the player without any regard to the direction the fish was facing. Also they have no problems swimming through rocks. It looks hilarious when a fish is suddenly pulled away sideways and the look on it face is just as baffled as is the players.Character customization has new gear again, but they don't seem to affect gameplay. What is the point of adding a weight belt when it has no impact on swimming? Also the gear is bugged and with a classic helmet (think big daddies from bioshock) obscures the pictures taken with camera, but not your view while swimming. Even without special gear, swimming backwards in an angle let's you see inside the divers face.Options are as bare bones as they were a year ago. No control mapping, no sound options etc. Now there is an option to 3d print your character, which is nice i guess. The game also supports VR but since i don't have the gear, i wasn't able to test it.My recommendation from year ago still stands but now i can say that World of diving is a work in progress with some progress. Forwards or backwards is whole another thing.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Original Review 25.10.2015World of Diving has a great idea: It let's you dive in realistic setting and around interesting landmarks like the wreck of Bismarck. Unfortunately in it's current state idea is the only thing it has.Biggest issue is that there has been very little progress since i bought this game a year ago. Wreck of Bismarck is a key selling point for this game. What happens when you try to dive under deck? "This area is not available yet". Some oysters you can open and find pearls inside, others just say "This oyster requires a tool to open (coming soon)". These two things you will see just after five minutes of gameplay and it has been like this for a year. So what has changed during the year? Framerate is much better than what it was a while ago. There are new diving suits. Also there is one new map which is different from the rest in it's setting and is kind of interesting.Graphics are just not good enough for this kind of game. This game needs a lot of work with light and shadow for it to have any kind of mood or atmosphere. For example your flashlight only lights but doesn't create shadows. Also, darkness really isn't dark: You will have no problems seeing inside a shipwreck with no natural light or flashlight. Those places should be pitch black! Movement does not kick up dust or anything like that, which would also be nice. Atleast in it's current state it runs well.The maps are quite boring aswell. For example you can dive inside some shipwrecks and in it are okay looking walls and maybe something like a torpedo bay but all the little things are missing. This means all signs that someone has lived there: No tools, no tin cans, no bottles, no cutlery, no clothes, nothing. The places are just empty shells. Real joy of i guess diving but atleast exploring lost places is the little stories that your mind creates from all of the items and their relations to places. Nothing like that is in this game. This also makes the photography part of the game meaningless since you can't create stories with it either.Options for graphics and such are just not there either. Can you adjust brightness? No. Can you adjust sound levels? No. Can you change key bindings? No. At the time of this review World of Diving is still very much a work in progress with little signs of progress. If you are interested, wait. Do not buy yet. If you just have to play a diving game, click the "More like this" button insted of "Add to cart".If you are still not sure then check the forums here and on the official website. See how active they are and what people are talking about.

								World of Diving is quite simply the best looking dive simulation. With a strong community to match, this game will force the genre to step up its game to match.World of Diving is currently in Alpha so my review may change. This game not only involves the simulation itself but also a vibrant online community and forum structure. The forums are filled with experienced real world divers, hardcore gamers, glitch finders, and people who simply wish they could dive in real life. But the one thing they all share is a desire to assist the developers Vertigo Games - create one of the best looking and best playing dive simulations on the market.As far as the game itself - it already looks beautiful even without any sort of optimization. This facet can only get better with the addition of a day/night cycle and environmental effects. However, as a person who has grown up on the beaches in South Florida, I can tell you one thing... they have captured the lifestyle perfectly so far. Water effects like ripple and water light diffusion are spot on. And diving to a deep wreck already conjures up a feeling of excitement as you get closer and closer, and it finally comes into view. Wrecks themselves have very early versions of their final textures - the last major update changed them dramatically from before. Yet they do have some weight to them - it feels like the objects have been underwater for some time.Fish interaction is nearly nonexistent - however, there are flashes of greatness - Dolphins playing and following divers to a wreck - Fish scattering if a shark swims into their school - Some fish not being overly concerned about the presence of a diver and others seeking safer places if you even look at them wrong.Overall, it is a promising alpha - and I encourage all fans of diving to join us in the World of Diving.

Early Access Review
								This is a reluctant recommendation of the game in its current state of developement.I'm reluctant to recommend because I'm finding it difficult to get excited to play the game and I'm finding its limitations of movement to be frustrating.You can't alter your axis and swim sideways which can be very odd underwater especially when swimming along the length of a sunken ship. I'd like to be able to turn to face the ships orientation and drag myself along certain objects and the lack of this makes that freedom of being underwater further away from how you actually feel in the game.The most frustrating part for me is that I see this as an MMO, not the usual MMO though, it's a Massively Missed Oportunity. If you've ever watched the TV show 'Tanked' you'll likely know what I'm getting at here. The living eco system in our seas is sorely missing from this game. The graphics are more in line with those aquariums in the show where the customer doesn't have enough time or knowledge to be able to look after a 'real life' aquarium with living rock and coral being substituted with acrylic, silicone, rubber, painted pieces that are too bright and unnatural.This may be ok for some but for me I'd like to see something closer to a real life reef than the artificial reefs that are used in that show. This day and age I think the devs could aim higher with transparency brought into the fray and annemonies and corals showing some real colours and movement, not these bright pink and blue stuck on cheapo immitations. Under water there's a lack of distance viewing which should have been an opportunity to really cram the details into the surrounding area of your swimming zone. I can't help but feel that the Unity 5 engine may be partially to blame for the lack of this. But I live in hope that the life that is sorely missing for me will be gradually introduced over time with this being still an early access release.From a lifelong marine tank enthusiasts perspective I can't help feeling really disappointed with the lack of realism but at the same time I do enjoy the game, so I have to give it the recommendation for that reason alone. I hope that over time the realism will be introduced to bring us a game that really uses current pc capabilities.

								Back when computers had just started becoming a household item, there was a lot of excitement about what might be and what would be, given time. This game is a fulfillment of that kind of promise personal computers had. My memory isn't perfect, but if I didn't hear someone longingly talk of someday being able to "explore underwater worlds" once, then it's only because I heard it more than once. And here we are; the future has become the present.I love aquatic biomes and the ability to visit one so detailed as this when I'm unable to do so in real life is something I adore having. The diversity of life you find in the waters of World of Diving necessarily doesn't equal what you'd see in an actual ocean, but there is enough variety that it stays interesting. As far as the fish go, they're so impressively detailed that you can easily tell their species at a glance if you know them in real life. And their behavior seems to differ slightly by species, as well.The sunken ships and the like are interesting and seem to be very well done. Those aren't as interesting to me as natural formations and flora and fauna, so I can't say much more than that about them. Well, I do remember that as I went through one sunken ship looking for Jack-o-Lanterns around Halloween, I remarked that the ship itself was a horror movie waiting to happen. Spooky. These sunken ships (and one plane, I believe) are often the hub or target of some of the available missions.This is such a beautiful experience and if you came looking at it with any hint of interest in the first place, you couldn't go wrong with it.

Early Access Review
								World of Diving is a fun, neat game about, well, diving. There are various dive sites with plenty of vibrant wildlife and plants. The main focus of each area are shipwrecks. While fun to explore, the wrecks themselves feel small and don't take a while to explore. While being very fleshed out, the dive sites also feel a little small, but this is still early in development. For an early-access game, I came across very, very few bugs. The mission editor is also fun to tinker with and easily lets you fully realize amazing coral reefs. It was also clear to me that the developers are working very hard to improve the game with polls on loading screens allowing you to vote for what content should be added.The core gameplay is simply diving. There are also missions which have you take certain pictures within an allotted amount of time. However, I didn't really come for the missions, they served as fun, little minigames that I did once in a while. The game is very set on experiencing things with a community, and in-game you could make all basic diving gestures.The game does get a little boring sometimes, but I enjoy coming back every so often to explore and look for things that I've mixed. There are in-game currencies, doubloons, and paid-for currencies, pearls, that allow you to get certain gear and even diving buddies. However, these are purely cosmetic.Overall, World of Diving is a fun, interesting game that I look forward to coming back to in the future. I can't wait to see how the game turns out from here and expect nothing but the best. This game has a lot of potential and Oculus Rift support makes the game a must-buy title for Rift users. Diving alone or with friends is a calming experience that is very refreshing coming off of the violence of most video games. This is a game for people who enjoy diving or nature, or are just looking for a cool, little sidegame with no real story elements that they can just pick-up and play without worrying about story elements or character progression.SCORE: 7.5/10

Early Access Review
								Update: I'll keep this short and sweet since there's not much to be said. Development on WoD has been painfully slow since I got this game a few months ago with very little actually being added to the game. The most recent update broke the game so the devs reverted back to an older update which is also broken. Despite my playtime and my original review the game is incredibly boring and bland, perhaps looking at it in hindsight is what has made me change my mind but there's very little to do apart from swim around and take Screenshots and the different maps don't really change anything. Furthermore there's very little communication from the devs apart from, and I'm paraphrasing here, "we're a very small team and most of our studio is focused on three other projects so it's hard for us to get things done" which you can see for yourself on one of the Steam forum discussions about this game being dead.On top of all this the game is now riddled with bugs and issues, many of which are game breaking for people trying to play it. None of the updates the devs are working on address any of these issues and each update seems to bring more and more issues to the game. WoD is a great example of Early Access done wrong and you should steer clear of this title until development picks up and interesting content is actually present in the game.Original Review: World of Diving is a diving simulator game that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In World of Diving you take to the water at a number of different locations ranging from a diving school (and the surrounding waters) to a sunken WWII ship. World of Diving has both multiplayer and singleplayer but due to the lack of players I've only experienced the singleplayer.This game does include microtransactions but everything in the game's store can be purchased with in-game money (if you can be bothered to collect the stupid amounts necessary).+Great graphics+Extremely relaxing to play+A number of different dive tools to help you out+Community challenges are well intergrated into each map+A reasonable amount of maps at the moment+There are some really cool cosmetic items in the shop if you like that kind of thing+Wildlife is well designed and they seem to behave quite realistically +Easy to use mission editor+/-Sea predators, such as sharks, pose no threat to you. It benefits how relaxing the game is but it does take away from the realism+/-Apart from some pretty unimaginative challenges which have you take pictures of things there's not much to do which is fine if you just want to have a relaxing experience but makes the game get boring quite quickly-Progress on this game is painfully slow, the devs do release weekly devblogs (which just show how little they get done each week) but it has been a very long time since the game actually got an update-Itemshop prices (whether you're using real currency or in-game currency) are way too high-Currently oxygen needs aren't in the game so you don't have to worry about your oxygen levels, takes away from the game's realism-The game has a 'brony' level. Whether you are a fan of bronies or not this map really breaks the realism of the game as of course you wouldn't find such a thing in the real world-The maps are very small and the wrecks within the maps also feel a bit too smallVerdict:6A nice diving game with great visuals that is let down by painfully slow updates and its lack of realism, I'd suggest buying this on sale and playing with friends.El K.

Early Access Review
								  World of Diving is a first person underwater exploration game in which you explore the wonders of the ocean.  If you were expecting anything along the lines of Far Sky or an action-style type of game, then you will be dissappointed, as World of Diving is literally an underwater exploration game.  And it's pretty good for what it is.    World of Diving's gameplay is very limited.  You can explore the sea, explore the wrecks of ships, and take pictures.  It is very little to work with, but the game is a state of Early Access, and for the most part, these activities are actually more fun than they sound.  You can explore the sea for treasure to unlock new gear (which is only aesthetic), explore wrecks with a group of people, which is really fun since the wrecks are designed in a nice way, and picture taking is picture taking, though there are challenges, which are nice and spice up the gameplay.    In terms of movement, movement feels very fluid, and feels pretty realistic, it actually makes you feel like your swimming, and it's cool.  In terms of sounds, the game has a very ambient sound design, there isn't music, there are only the sounds of the ocean.  It's very immersive, though it would be cool to see an addition like an MP3 player.  In the graphics department, World of Diving shines.  Everything graphically is pretty beautiful, with the exception of some character animations and dolphin animations.  Besides that, the visuals lock in the feel of realism that the game creates so well in every department.  The  flashlight is also very good, the lighting visuals are superb.  Overall, it is obvious that the devs have a serious passion for what they are creating, and while it is a bit lackluster at the moment, it is still very fun.  If you have ever wanted to explore the ocean without getting wet, World of Diving is the best choice for that experience.

Early Access Review
								A couple years ago, I had the fortune to spend a week at a tropical resort with a little fish-filled cove attached to it. I spent every spare moment with my little waterproof camera snapping pictures of all the amazing life under the water, and then I spent days at home happily going through and saving all the photos that turned out, on my computer.That's what this game is, but in larger locales that often include wrecks to explore.If this appeals to you, you'll love it. If it doesn't, move along.No, you can't harpoon whales, wrestle sharks or lasergun aliens. It's fish. And plants. And water. And a camera. Which, if you are not completely warped by the idea that you have to be "winning" something in a game, can be incredibly engaging.Play using audio headphones if you don't have a VR headset yet - it will vastly increase your immersion*. I'll be buying the Oculus Rift for this game.*pun intended.Edit: One more thing that will be helpful if you're on the fence. I find that you need an exceptionally good machine to run this game. My little integrated-graphics laptop cannot do it, and it wasn't until very recently that I got it back up and running on my older gen quad core desktop with a 1 GB graphics card. I can run most MMOs I've tried pretty close to max graphics settings, but in this game, have had a lot of lag around the diving base, and it keeps forcing me to lowest, or second-lowest, settings. I love that the graphics have been upgraded since the pre-Steam days when I played regularly, but I do wish there was the ability to turn it down to the graphics levels they had available before.But hey, it's early access, and a lot can happen before Oculus finally releases their consumer headset, right? I do hope Vertigo keeps in mind that a casual sort of game like this needs to be accessible across a wide range of rigs though. A lot of amazing games have shot themselves in the foot by putting visual quality before accessibility.

								Apparently, people didn't like my original review. So let me try this again with more elaboration. I'm not deleting and re-typing a new review so all my upvotes and downvotes will remain from the previous review.The atmosphere, the graphics, the feeling of actually being there swimming and diving is excellent and top notch. The game itself, though, is hardly there.Your character can be somewhat customized and upgraded as you play and earn virtual currencies. The charcater models and textures are excellent. This game has one of the best first person views of any game. If I had a VR set it would only multiply how awesome it is to see my flippers and hands and chest and even my groin while swimming around. Top-Notch stuff there.There are very well detailed enviroments and every level/map/zone is different than each other keeping that part fresh and unique. Each level/map/zone, though very detailed, are relatively small. In comparison they are about the size of a Dragon Ball Xenoverse stage (which is not very big), possibly even compared to a Quake III standard map size.The "game" part of this game consist of mini tasks like snapping photos collecting objects like tedious fetch quests. Follow the marker and do the obvious.I think what I was more expecting from this game was a casual exploration game where maybe I could catalog stuff and aquatic life and just swim around in a large(er) space than what the game has to offer. Especially if the game has VR support that'd be what I want to do the most. The wonder, the awe, and the getting lost in underwater exploration factors are just not there.Yeah I know the game is still Early Access. But after so many years it just needs more TLC than it gets. If the game had some larger maps and just a basic free roam mode I would change my recommendation.Good day.

Early Access Review
								This is a good game for the Vive, especially if you need to ease non-VR players into a movement-based Vive game. It's beautiful, the maps are suitably different and nicely laid out, the fish are fun to watch. Downside: there's very little content. At this point (Early Access) it's still basically a sandbox world with a few photo missions and that's it. The world and gameplay are solid, even on the Vive, but aside from swimming around looking at things, there's just not much to *do* in the game. I was hoping this would be a replacement for Endless Ocean: Blue World, and I think it has the potential to be, but for now it's just a very pretty sandbox.Still, there's more content coming so I'm optimistic about what World of Diving will become. And it's a good game to show off your Vive if you have people nervous about getting attacked by sharks; nothing really bothers you in this game so your VR-timid relations can swim around without any inconvenient jump-scares.
